title: How to Make an Earbud Cord Caddy

steps.headline: Gather your materials.
steps.description: Abandoned children's foam puzzle pieces work very well for this project, as do cheap "flip-flop" or "Zori" type shoes.

steps.headline:
{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/5\/5c\/A2a_871.JPG","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/5\/5c\/A2a_871.JPG","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":439,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":724.5333333333333,"licensing":"

Image by: Uploader
\nLicense: Creative Commons<\/a>\n<\/p><\/div>"} Fold in half.
steps.description: Draw your pattern. Your caddy should be approximately 1.5 inches (3.8 cm) wide by 3 inches (7.5 cm) long, so start with an appropriately sized piece of paper and fold it in quarters.

steps.headline: Cut out your pattern and see if you like the looks of it.
steps.description: The ends need to be wider than the middle, and it should be no longer than 4 inches (10 cm), but other than that, your imagination is the only limiting factor.

steps.headline: Trace your pattern(s) onto the foam.
Cut the foam.
steps.description: Place another piece of foam under your cutting to protect the table surface.

steps.headline: Cut slits in both ends.
steps.description: Widen the inside end of the slit to make a better holder.

steps.headline: Bevel the edges using a pair of scissors.
Trim any corners or sharp points to round them over.
Wrap your earbud cord by tucking the plug into one end of your caddy and winding the cord to the desired length before tucking the other end into the caddy.

tyn: 3/8ths to 1/2 inch thick foam rubber or "craft foam".  The sort used for Children's toys and puzzles works well, as do the footpads from the cheaper types of flip flops.  Avoid the harder, rubbery floor mats.
X-Acto Knife or similar bladed tool.
text:
Gather your materials. Abandoned children's foam puzzle pieces work very well for this project, as do cheap "flip-flop" or "Zori" type shoes. {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/5\/5c\/A2a_871.JPG","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/5\/5c\/A2a_871.JPG","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":439,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":724.5333333333333,"licensing":"

Image by: Uploader
\nLicense: Creative Commons<\/a>\n<\/p><\/div>"} Fold in half. Draw your pattern. Your caddy should be approximately 1.5 inches (3.8 cm) wide by 3 inches (7.5 cm) long, so start with an appropriately sized piece of paper and fold it in quarters. Cut out your pattern and see if you like the looks of it. The ends need to be wider than the middle, and it should be no longer than 4 inches (10 cm), but other than that, your imagination is the only limiting factor. Trace your pattern(s) onto the foam. Cut the foam. Place another piece of foam under your cutting to protect the table surface. Cut slits in both ends. Widen the inside end of the slit to make a better holder. Bevel the edges using a pair of scissors. Trim any corners or sharp points to round them over. Wrap your earbud cord by tucking the plug into one end of your caddy and winding the cord to the desired length before tucking the other end into the caddy.
sentences: Abandoned children's foam puzzle pieces work very well for this project, as do cheap "flip-flop" or "Zori" type shoes.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/5\/5c\/A2a_871.JPG","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/5\/5c\/A2a_871.JPG","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":439,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":724.5333333333333,"licensing":"

Image by: Uploader
\nLicense: Creative Commons<\/a>\n<\/p><\/div>"} Fold in half.
Your caddy should be approximately 1.5 inches (3.8 cm) wide by 3 inches (7.5 cm) long, so start with an appropriately sized piece of paper and fold it in quarters.
Cut out your pattern and see if you like the looks of it.
The ends need to be wider than the middle, and it should be no longer than 4 inches (10 cm), but other than that, your imagination is the only limiting factor.
Trace your pattern(s) onto the foam.
Place another piece of foam under your cutting to protect the table surface.
Widen the inside end of the slit to make a better holder.
Bevel the edges using a pair of scissors.
Trim any corners or sharp points to round them over.
Wrap your earbud cord by tucking the plug into one end of your caddy and winding the cord to the desired length before tucking the other end into the caddy.
